James P. Gunderson wrote:

> By standardizing our testcase format, and specifying a defined expected 
> result, and loading the actual, this also allows us to reduce many of 
> the asserts to
> 
> assertEquals("E: " + expected + " G: " + actual, expected, actual);

I hope you don't actually write this, since assertEquals() already 
builds that exact failure message. :)

> Like any attempt to have a regular format, it can lead to 
> inefficiencies. But we generally feel that the tradeoff is worth it. It 
> also makes it much easier to bring someone new up to speed - they can 
> worry less about the syntax of the failure message and more about the 
> content.

It's always nice to use simple rules that lead to satisfactory behavior. 
Have you never wished, though, that the failure message told you a 
little something about the root cause of the failure?
